One gram pieces of Microciona were dissociaTed in 40 mls. filTered sea
waTer by expressing iT Through #20 bolTing silk and Then filTering The suspen-
sion Through a double Thickness of The silk. Several drops of The suspension
were sealed under a coverslip wiTh vaseline. PhoTography was performed wiTh a
Wild phase-conTrasT (M-20) microscope and Bolex camera. Observafions were made

Upon dissociafion The cells rapidly seTTle To The boTTom of The chamber
and begin To reaggregafe. The individual cells move abouT, fusing boTh wiTh
The oTher cells and wiTh aggregafes when conTacT is made befween Them. Some
of The cells are much more acTive Than ofhers; however, There is no apparenT
basis for This difference. ln general, The movemenf of individual cells is
limifed To relaTively shorT disTances. Fusion of The cells involves only The
hyaloplasm, The granuloplasm of The aggregaTed cells remaining discreTe. Fre-
quenTly Three To five cells and/or young aggregafes come TogeTher simulfaneously
as if There were a muTual aTTracTion.
The archeocyTes move by means of clear lobose pseudopodia. These pseudo-
podia aTTach To The subsTraTum and conTracT suddenly, advancing The cell in a
jerky manner. Filopodia are also exfended.
The coanocyTes, The oTher major cell Type in The suspensions, move by
means of flagella which are soon losT, and by lobose pseudopodia. There has been
some confusion as To The nafure of The coanocyTes in The cell suspensions. lT
appears (Wilson, ThaT The elongaTed, flagellaTed cells of rare occurence
ThaT were formerly ThoughT To be coanocyTes are in facT The flagellafed cells
of embryos and ThaT The coanocyTes are small (4-5 diamefer) rounded hyaline
cells wiTh a few small red granules.
The aggregaTes puT forTh pseudopodia of The common hyaloplasm, The gran-
uloplasm of The cells mainfaining a nearly spherical shape. FrequenTly a single
large lobopodia is puT TorTh, and in many cases The surface of The aggregaTes
bubble vigorously as These lobopodia are exfended and wifhdrawn. Occasionally
The granuloplasm of a single cell migraTes ouT info The exTended hyaloplasm.
The aggregaTes move over considerable disfances, Traversing as much as mm. in
a five hour period. indeed, The small aggregafes are very acTive, sweeping up
isolaTed cells as They move abouf.
Tracings of The rouTes of The cells and early aggregafes were made from
lOOx films covering a 5"hour period. An analysis of These paThs show ThaT The
rouTes Taken by The cells and aggregafes are random. However, on occasion a cell
or early aggregaTe was seen To follow closely The TorTuous rouTe Taken by anoTher
cell or aggregaTe a shorT Time before. There was no indicafion of cellular
producTs laid down by The cells over which oTher cells mighT Travel. AT 
There was no evidence of membranes or fibrous maTerial produced by The cells.
Galfsoff reporfed ThaT archeocyTes somefimes lose small biTs of hyaloplasm
which mark The rouTe Taken by The cell and ThaT These are wiped up by oTher cells
which move over Them. Perhaps These droplefs which presenT physical irregulariTies
in The subsfrafum serve To direcT The paThs of oTher cells.
